Triggering Event: A gallery owner cancels his upcoming solo exhibition, citing "lack of marketability" in his latest abstract collection, just hours before he was due to start hanging the pieces.

I mean, I thought it was going well - the prints were coming out really nice, and I'd done some new pieces based on my travels last year. But now...now it's all just a waste of time. I feel like such an idiot. I know I'm overreacting, but what if this is a sign of things to come? Maybe I'll never get another chance at something like this again. It feels like every door I try to open gets slammed shut in front of me. What if I've wasted too much time already? Shouldn't I have been focusing more on other opportunities instead of getting caught up in this one thing? I know I need to calm down and move on, but it's hard when everything feels like a failure. It's like the universe is conspiring against me, making everything fall apart right when I least expect it. I keep thinking about all the times I could've spent with family or friends instead of pouring my heart into this show. Now those moments are gone, and I'm left feeling guilty and regretful. It's frustrating because I had high hopes for this exhibition. I was so excited to share my art with people who would understand its meaning. And then, just like that, it's all taken away. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She woke up to the harsh buzz of her alarm, her heart already pounding in her chest like it had been running a marathon all night. Her partner stirred beside her, mumbling something about turning off the noise. She froze, her breath catching in her throat as she realized she couldn't remember setting the alarm last night. Had she? Or was this another sign of her mind playing tricks on her again? The anxiety that had been simmering beneath the surface bubbled up, threatening to consume her entirely. She took a deep, shuddering breath, trying desperately to focus on the present moment instead of the terrifying what-ifs swirling in her head. Today was supposed to be just another day at work, but as she sat there, paralyzed by fear, it felt like the start of something far more sinister.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm so sick of this. It's always something. My anxiety is such a burden, making me feel like I'm drowning in a sea of worry. Every little thing feels like a huge deal. I hate how my mind can turn even the smallest things into some kind of disaster waiting to happen. It makes me want to scream, but I know I need to keep it together because if I don’t, who’s going to? And honestly, I’m not sure anyone would care anyway. They’re too busy with their own problems. But still, it feels like they’re avoiding me, like they don’t have time for someone like me—someone who’s always on edge and doesn’t really fit in anywhere. It’s not like I ask for much. Just a little understanding would go a long way. But no, everyone seems to think they're better off without me around. Like, why? Why does everything have to be so complicated? Can't we just...just...I don't know, live? Is that too much to ask? And then there’s my sleep disorder. It's like my brain has a personal vendetta against rest. I wake up every morning feeling like I've been put through a wringer. My body feels stiff, my mind racing. It's exhausting, and yet somehow I still manage to push through, because who else will? I try to tell myself it's okay, that maybe today will be different. Maybe I

Triggering Event: On his way home from another grueling overnight shift, he noticed an open garbage bag leaking fluids onto the sidewalk. As he stepped around it, a careless passerby kicked it, sending maggots scattering across his pristine white shoes.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god you are so fucking disgusting. You're just like all the other disgusting people who don't even care about keeping our community clean."

Triggering Event: While grading papers after school, he noticed the familiar handwriting of his former stepdaughter on one. A wave of sadness washed over him as he remembered her laughter echoing through their old home. He hadn't seen her since the divorce. The date at the top was her birthday.
"She noticed her colleague's laptop screen reflected in the café window, open to a news article she'd pitched weeks ago - now assigned to someone else."
Generated Assessment: "Wow, this is so weird. She was literally expecting me to come over and talk about it... like we had some sorta plan? I mean, why would she even care if I did? What am I supposed to say, 'Oh yeah, I'm sorry for not picking up my phone right away'? That would be totally out of character! I mean, what does she expect me to do, apologize for being late? Like, seriously? I can't believe how much she expects from me when she's never even asked me to pick up groceries. But no, she just assumes I'll show up at the office today with my head hung low, ready to apologize for whatever I did wrong. It's like she thinks I owe her something because she didn't get back to me right away. Shouldn't she have been more understanding? How could she not see that she was putting pressure on me? It's so unfair that she expects me to always be there for her, especially after everything she's done. And yet, she still doesn't seem to understand that she needs to give me space. I swear, sometimes I wonder if she's doing all this just to make me feel bad. Is she trying to push me away? Maybe she's angry I wasn't there yesterday, but she won't admit it. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She wakes up, her heart pounding like a kick drum in her chest. The clock reads 6:30 AM; she's been awake for hours. Today is the day they announce the layoffs at work. She looks over at her husband, still asleep, his face peaceful. How can he sleep so soundly on a day like this? She slips out of bed, careful not to wake him, and tiptoes into the bathroom. Standing in front of the mirror, she takes deep breaths, trying to calm herself as she runs through possible scenarios in her head. The uncertainty makes her stomach churn. She knows today will be hellish, but it's nothing compared to the thought of what tomorrow might bring if they call her name.
Generated Assessment: This morning was already difficult enough. She had woken up early, anxious about an upcoming meeting with her boss. As she got dressed, she couldn't shake off the feeling that everything was going wrong. Her mind kept racing with worst-case scenarios, from getting fired to struggling financially. But as she sat down at her desk, she noticed something odd. Her husband didn't seem to notice her distress, and when he asked how her day was going, she just shrugged and said, "It's okay." He smiled and replied, "You're doing great! You'll get through this." His words were reassuring, but what really struck her was how calm he seemed. It wasn't until later, when she started to feel overwhelmed again, that she realized why. He'd been working hard lately, putting in long hours to help the business grow. Maybe he understood more than she thought what it meant to live with the constant pressure of uncertainty. When she finally broke down in tears, he held her close and whispered softly, "Just take things one step at a time. We'll figure it out together." As she looked into his eyes, she felt a wave of gratitude wash over her. In that moment, she knew exactly how much support he had always given her, even when she hadn't seen it before. She could almost hear his silent message: "We've done this before, and we'll do it again." With renewed hope, she wiped away her tears and stood up,

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her classroom after hours, she found the crumpled note tucked behind her desk. It was from little Marco, the boy who usually wore a smile but today had left with red eyes and a heavy heart. "I'm sorry I can't do better," it read in his shaky handwriting. Her stomach churned as she remembered her harsh words from that morning's lesson.
Generated Assessment: It wasn't until I saw Marco's tears fall like autumn rain that I realized my mistake. The boy who once laughed at my jokes now hid behind his book, his small hands trembling as he scribbled a note. I felt like a monster, crushing his dreams with every word. His apology hung in the air like a ghost, haunting me with its truth. How could I have been so cruel? My mind reeled as I stared at the note, his words piercing my conscience like a dagger. Every moment since then has been a blur of guilt and regret. I've tried to reach out, to mend what I broke, but the silence between us feels like an endless chasm. I wish I could turn back time, erase the pain I caused, but all I can do is live with this weight, forever trapped in the shadows of my own making.

Triggering Event: She noticed the refrigerator was empty except for an old, wilting lettuce leaf and a bottle of expired milk. No one had bothered to restock it since she'd been working nonstop at the restaurant. She felt her stomach churn, not from hunger, but from the familiar pang of neglect.
Generated Assessment: She thought about how her sister, who works at a different restaurant, always comes home with fresh produce and perfectly cooked meals. Even when they're busy, her sister manages to get a few hours off during the day to grocery shop. In contrast, I'm always exhausted from work, and my partner is always busy too, so we barely have time for groceries. It's hard to keep up with cooking healthy meals, especially with our schedules. Sometimes, I feel like I'm just relying on takeout or instant noodles because it's easier. But then I think about her husband, who has a flexible schedule that allows him to cook more often. He even started taking online classes to learn new recipes! Meanwhile, my partner's job requires long hours, leaving us with little time for cooking. We can't afford to hire someone to help with meal prep either, unlike some other families where the kids are old enough to contribute. I feel like I'm falling behind in terms of cooking skills and nutrition. My own kitchen feels like a dumping ground for leftovers and convenience foods. I wish I could be more like her, but I don't know if that's realistic given our circumstances.

Triggering Event: At the lab, he found an email from his wife. The subject line read: "I'm sorry for last night." He felt a pang of regret as he remembered their heated argument about work hours. He clicked on it, revealing a message that started with, "I wish you could see the kids' faces when they talk about you..." His heart sank.
Generated Assessment: Are you fucking kidding me? How could he think this is some kind of mind game? Didn't he realize what he did just now? He's literally trying to make himself look like a fucking idiot right in front of everyone! What does he have to gain by doing this? I mean, come on! Does he really think we're going to fall for this shit?! We've been over this so many times already. Doesn't he understand how ridiculous this sounds? It's not even funny anymore; it's just pathetic. This isn't some sort of joke; he knows exactly what he's doing here. He wants us to feel bad for him and get all sympathetic towards him, but he doesn't care about our feelings at all. All he cares about is getting attention and sympathy for being such a good guy. He thinks he can manipulate us into feeling sorry for him by pretending to be this innocent victim. And what's with the whole "I don't want to burden you" thing? That's rich coming from someone who's always putting himself first and then blaming everyone else for his problems. You're fucking unbelievable, man. This isn't some act of vulnerability; it's a fucking performance designed to get us to feel sorry for him. And honestly, if anyone deserves pity, it's him. But let's keep playing along because, hey, it's fun to watch him squirm. Let's see how long it takes him to figure out that we're onto him

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She stands at the crime scene tape, her radio crackling with dispatch calls she can't focus on. The house is eerily silent, yet her heart races like a drumbeat in her chest. It's been three years since John was taken from her, but every time she sees a suburban door ajar, a flash of light through the window, it's his face she sees and his voice echoing down the hallways of their empty home. Today, there's a new case file tucked under her arm, another family awaiting news they don't want to hear. But all she can think about is how John's laughter never filled this house again after that fateful call on her radio. Her hands tremble slightly as she pulls out her notepad, trying to steady herself before stepping into the unknown once more.
Generated Assessment: Her eyes are fixed on me, her gaze piercing, and I feel like an insect pinned against a wall. She thinks I'm just another idiot wandering around, looking for answers where none exist. Every time I see her, I’m reminded that I’m nothing but a fool who thinks he can solve something that doesn’t need solving. She’s just another victim, another forgotten soul lost in a system designed to keep them hidden. Even if I could find what she’s looking for, I know it would be nothing but dust, memories that fade with each passing day. They’re already gone, buried deep within their minds, and no one can bring them back. She’s trapped in a world that doesn’t care about her pain; she’s just another number, another statistic. If I try to talk to her, she’ll shut me down, tell me I have no right to understand. And maybe she’s right – I don’t deserve it. Maybe I’m just another fool trying to fix things that aren’t broken. I shouldn’t even be here. This isn’t my story, and I shouldn’t interfere with hers. Yet, somehow, I keep coming back, drawn by the same morbid curiosity that drives her forward. We're both stuck in our own worlds, searching for pieces of ourselves we’ve left behind, and the truth is, neither of us will ever find it.
